Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Improvement of NMR experimental conditions for better identifying metabolite mixtures: Tools to investigate microbial responses to external stress

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major scientific goals of this project were to learn new technieques and study metabolic responses that may be relevant to the production of biofuels. By participating in this project I successfully conducted in vivo nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy experiments using E. coli.

We initially overlooked the fact that E. coli cultured in an NMR tube will be growing under anaerobic conditions. Previous data obtained while studying the metabolism of E. coli under butanol stress was conducted under aerobic conditions. This appeared to add another level of stress to the organism, and as such it was necessary to devote time to redefining the parameters required for growth. Furthermore, I decided that it would also be interesting to determine if metabolism was affected differently when E. coli were supplied with different carbon sources and therefore compared growth on glucose versus xylose.

The data showed that E. coli grown on glucose or xylose did not display significant differences in growth rate in the presence or absence of butanol. However, E. coli supplemented with glucose and grown in the presence of butanol were unable to reach the same optical density as E. coli supplemented with xylose in the presence of butanol. Results from in vivo NMR indicate that the major metabolites produced and released from E. coli were lactate, succinate, acetate and ethanol. All of these indicated that when E. coli was under butanol stress, that fermentative mechanisms of energy production were preferred. Furthermore, close inspection of the data showed that the levels of these metabolites, especially ethanol, were highest from E. coli grown on glucose and stressed with butanol. These results most likely explain why E. coli were unable to reach a higher optical density when grown on glucose in the presence of butanol. In the larger picture, this is an interesting result. The larger goal is to be able to produce biobutanol from E. coli to serve as an alternative fuel. What we learn from my study is that E. coli engineered for biobutanol production will need to have pathways that lead to ethanol production removed. The reasons are two-fold: 1) it will be less efficient if resources are diverted toward ethanol production and 2) we should want to reduce the stress by only subjecting the organism to one type of toxic solvent.

Another goal of my project was to reach out to my colleagues and teach them methods that are used my home lab at the University of Wisconsin. To accomplish this goal I gave a workshop on software called rNMR, which is software my group has developed specifically for the analysis of NMR based metabolomics data. The workshop was well received and resulted in two of my colleagues requesting private and more detailed instruction on the use of this software.

Finally, it was my goal to improve my understanding of the Japanese language and culture. Without a doubt, my ability to comprehend written and spoken Japanese has vastly improved as a result of spending 10 weeks in Japan. I took many opportunities to speak Japanese not only with my colleagues but also with other individuals that I met during my daily life. In one instance I was attending a fireworks display in Yokohama and had the pleasure of talking with a man who was enrolled in nursing school.
